item.comment: That's Life is a game you'll be loving one minute and cursing the next. I had 2 fun games with my family recently. One player said "I hate this game!" while smiling, laughing, and asking for another round. It's heavily luck influenced, but still provides you with interesting decisions each turn. Plus there are many opportunities to screw over another player, and this is what makes the game so fun and funny sometimes. The game has great interactivity. It also accommodates a wide player range (2-6) which is helpful in a casual gaming situation, and it scales well. I appreciate Kramer's ability to design enjoyable games that can fit in at various difficulty levels yet always remain interesting and engaging.

item.name: Through the Desert
item.comment: Interesting gameplay but a little bit chaotic. I would likely rate it higher if it wasn't for the colour scheme being extremely unfriendly to colourblind players. I'll try it once or twice more and if it seems worth it I will paint some of the pieces, otherwise I may sell or trade this away. UPDATE: Traded

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Europe
item.comment:
I've only played this once, but based on my plays of Nordic Countries, I feel comfortable rating this one about the same. I like learning the European cities, and I like the bright colours and attractive map. There is also a fair amount of strategy in deciding what to pursue. The mechanics are intuitive and easy to teach, and I'm looking forward to introducing this one to my family.
Update: We never seem to play this, my partner is not a big fan because with 4 or 5 players there is too much downtime between turns, when the turns should be simple and quick. She likes Nordic Countries with less players better. Up for trade now.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Nordic Countries
item.comment: So I finally got around to trying a TTR game, and liked it more than expected! I also really enjoy the attractive, large map, because I plan to visit Northern Europe soon and this will help me become familiar with the geography. I have the Europe map too now and will be trying that one next. This one is useful though as I more commonly play 2 or 3 player games.

item.name: Tikal
item.comment: My favourite Euro game. The mechanics are elegant, the components are beautiful, it scales well from 2 to 4, it's easy to teach, and has fun tactical decision making. Read my review for more details.

item.name: Tikal II: The Lost Temple
item.comment: The rules were a bit fiddly and there was some AP during the first play, but I really enjoyed this. The different scoring options allow you to focus on a different strategy than your opponent. So far it seems this is one advantage over the previous Tikal (where treasures are very important), but I'd like to play it a lot more to see if one of the different scoring options proves itself to be more important. The one downside I can see so far, compared to another of Kramer's new games, Asara, is that the rules in this one are a little bit harder to teach and the scoring options less obvious than Asara, so it might be less ideal for casual gamers, but I'm not sure if it has the depth to satisfy more serious gamers.

item.name: Tobago
item.comment: My first impression so far is that the game is definitely interesting and beautiful, and the mechanics are quite neat and unique. These are all factors that are important to me in a game, however the actual gameplay is not quite as fun as I would like. It seems to drag at times but this could just be due to slow play as we learn the game. It's still enjoyable though and is definitely unlike any other game in my collection. I'm curious about how it will play now that we are past the learning stage. Edit: After another play the pace seemed improved, it plays faster when all the players know the game. Raised my rating a bit.

item.name: Tokaido
item.comment: Simple flowing decisions. Lots of different ways to get points and often they don't seem much different from each other, but eventually someone does come out ahead. Easy to teach and engaging for new players.

item.name: Torres
item.comment:
I've played this once, but had problems with a couple of the rules, so I need to replay it before rating it. My intitial reaction is that neither the theme or the gameplay seem as fun as other similar titles by these designers, and the rules seem less intuitive, so I'm not sure how often this will get played.
Update: Finally learned how to play this better by playing online. Still not my favourite by these designers though. It's pretty mathy and abstract.

item.name: Upwords
item.comment: An interesting twist on Scrabble, stacking letters can be kind of fun, but I got bored of this rather quickly. There is not really much to it.

item.name: UR
item.comment:
This is essentially an abstract area control game with a set collection mechanic for victory points. The theme is thin but matches up with the action mechanics in an intuitive way. This is a great example of a game that holds a surprising amount of depth within a simple ruleset. It can definitely be a brain burner though, and can sometimes result in some AP. I like the design a lot, both mechanically and graphically, but it is hard to get to the table because it is fairly deep and not immediately visually appealing to someone unfamiliar with it.
Update: I've been enjoying playing this on mabiweb. It's easier to find players, and playing it turn based allows more time to contemplate your moves. Update 2: Had a fun 3 player face to face session. There was some AP but it was still quite satisfying.

item.name: Valdora
item.comment: For some reason I really enjoy this pickup and delivery game. The rules are simple and elegant, however the theme is a bit abstracted. Nice art and components too. The ending seemed to drag a bit once but I think that was only due to new players who were unsure what to do.

item.name: Vineta
item.comment:
Our first (and only) play did not go really well. We spent a lot of time referencing the player aid to try to understand what the special cards did. Some of them were not worded well, and there was a mistake on the reference sheet (2 of the card descriptions are reversed, and we didn't realize until close to the end of the game). The amount of time spent trying to figure out the rules seemed disproportionate to the amount of strategy you could use and the amount of control you have over the outcome of the game. Many of the special cards are very situational, so you spend time figuring out what it does, only to have it sit unused in your hand. The cards to move or protect houses seemed especially useless, because in order to play them, you have to miss out on playing a wave towards that turn's wave surge, which reduces your chances of sharing in the prize points for that round. And there is no way to know in advance if the place you move the houses to will be any more safe than where they were.
At the end of the game, the last wave surge was tied, which means all players play another wave card to break the tie. Unfortunately I ended the game with full hand of useless event cards, and no wave cards to use towards the tie.
It's possible that some of these problems may have been related to the fact that we tried it with only 3 players, the lowest number you can play with. This means there are less houses in play, which may make the house-related special cards less useful (I can't say for sure though). The rule interpretation problems would certainly be reduced on a second play, but due to the poor experience I had the first time, I can't see myself being motivated to try again.
item.conditiontext: this version is the international version with the full board. It includes English, French, and German rules.

item.name: Wacky Wizard Game
item.comment:
The components are really great, but unfortunately it uses a roll and move mechanic with a spinner, and one of the spinner results totally changes your win condition. Totally random game. It might make a good kids game, but I'm not sure I even want to expose kids I might one day have to such a random-fest. The other option is that the components could be re-used for a new game design.
I'm not sure what to do with this one, as it's really old and cool looking, but unplayable. Want to trade it from me?

item.name: Wasabi!
item.comment: I was pleasantly surprised by this game. I was expecting it to get by mostly on theme, but the mechanics were well designed and intuitive, and the gameplay was competitive and tactical. I also love the bright colours and graphic design work. It was easy to teach to non-gamers on the fly. A perfect complement to a great sushi night I just held.

item.name: WildLife
item.comment: On first impression I like this one, but I need more plays to really decide what I think. I love the theme and the way the movement/expansion and attack mechanics work.

item.name: Wildlife Adventure
item.comment: This is a great game for learning about different animal species, and a game I would look forward to introducing to my kids if I have some one day. It also scaled down to 2 players much better than I expected. Some luck is involved in winning, and I'm not crazy about the Chance cards, but overall I was pleased with this game. I am curious about the Expedition version though.

item.name: Wiraqocha
item.comment: Only tried it once so far. I really love the art and theme, and the mechanics seem solid. With only 2 players there was not quite enough interaction. Need to try this again with more players.

item.name: Witch's Brew
item.comment: I really like this, and it has been a hit with all of my friends. It shares some elements with other games that I like such as San Juan (role selection), and Dominion (using action cards, buying victory cards), but the theme is way more fun than either of those games. I really love the wooden droplet tokens, and the fun art style. Everyone gets a kick out of the part of the game where you announce your chosen role. So be it!

item.name: Wiz-War (eighth edition)
item.comment:
For some reason I really like this one, even though it seems like the winner needs a significant dose of luck. I find it is one of those games where it is fun to see what you can pull off even if it may not help you win. For the most part I think FFG did an alright job on the reprint, but I haven't played the original. I kinda wish they wouldn't mess around with the rules when reprinting games, but on the other hand the rules changes made here seem pretty simple and reasonable.
Update: The fun seems to vary based on which card sets you are using. Some of the cards are not useful enough to justify the time taken to read their overly wordy text. I think I will try making my own mix of cards before I play this next time.
